title: JSON Schema for the Shape-Color Sorting MTB Test.
description: This schema shares many elements across all Mobile Toolbox tests, but it is specific to the Shape-Color Sorting task. Common elements across tasks appear in the definitions section (though not all of them are utilized herein), but the main properties section defines the task-specific representations of it.

specialStepsIndicators.description: This definition will be reused for instructions, practice, interruptions, etc., as needed and described in the element properties, below.

timemarks.description: The timestamp when an event occurred, following ISO 8601 formatting conventions

locale.description: localization for the phone on which the task was administered - note that this is metadata passed by the app and thus not enumerated herein

jsonSchema.description: This is the URL that points to the self-referenced schema. It points to a specific tag/commit on GitHub against which the data should validate.

MSSControlEvent.description: This is used within interactions to record the type of event that is occurring. It is an enumerated field.

testVersion.description: The version of the task that was administered in this record. Note that this is a number stored as a string

position.description: An integer used to record the order of screen presentation throughout the task.

responseInt.description: Many measures use an integer for recording a response, with the integer representing the button order on the screen (left-to-right, top-to-bottom). The exclusiveMinimum is globally set to 0 in the definitions section, with the maximum set on a task-specific basis within the `steps` and `stepHistory` sections.

responseStr.description: Some measures have users key in a response, which is then stored as a string. Restrictions on string formatting are set on a task-specific basis.

itemScore.description: Almost all tasks use integers for recording scores. Minimum and maximum values are task-specific.

responseTime.description: Time in milliseconds for a response to occur. This is only used on tasks where timing is part of the scoring process. Otherwise time needs to be derived for a specific analytic purpose.

type.description: Some Android versions add a `type` field to the taskData. This is an optional placeholder to accomodate that.

taskName.description: This is the test/task name as administered. It will be automatically provided as part of metadata. However, to ensure that the correct task is validating against this schema, it is restricted in values.

schemaIdentifier.description: This is a text-based identifier for the unique schema and schema version.

scores.description: The scores element is stored as an object with its own properties. All scores are expected.

nAnticipationPractice.description: Number of anticipation errors during practice items.

nAnticipationLive.description: Number of anticipation errors during live items.

rawScore.description: Number of trials on which a person correctly responded. This must be within the range of 0-30, given the number of trials across the test.

totalErrors.description: Total number of errors (all types) that a person made during the task. This includes anticipation errors and inaccurate responses on the live trials.

rateScore.description: This is the ratio of number of correct trials to the total reaction time across all trials (correct and incorrect). It is reported as number correct per second, so although the response time in the `steps` element is reported in integer milliseconds, it is converted to seconds for scoring. The minimum is established based off of zero correct; the maximum is based off of all correct in 100ms per trial (which is highly unlikely and exceedingly fast)

steps.description: This records all of the items/steps administered during this assessment. It records the response and score.

userInteractionIdentifier.description: This was formerly called `identifier`, but has been renamed for clarity. It is used within interactions to indicate the UI element with which the person is interacting.
